pack.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to put things into cases, bags etc ready for a trip somewhere
pack.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: I forgot to pack my razor.
Kelly packed her things before breakfast.
You’d better pack your bags. We’re leaving in an hour.
Shall I pack us a picnic?
pack.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to put something into a box or other container, so that it can be moved, sold, or stored
pack.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Now wild mushrooms are available all year, packed in handy 25 g boxes.
pack.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to go in large numbers into a space, or to make people or animals do this, until the space is too full
pack.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Fifty thousand fans packed into the stadium.
The sheep had been packed into a truck and transported without food or water.
pack.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to cover or fill an object with soft material so that it does not get damaged
pack.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Glass must be packed in several layers of paper.
pack.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to press snow, soil, sand etc down so that it becomes hard and firm
pack.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: something wrapped in paper or packed in a box and then sent by post or taken somewhere
pack.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Send away for your free information pack today.
pack.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a small container, usually made of paper, that something is sold in
pack.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: a 10 oz pack of frozen peas
pack.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: a bag that you carry on your back, especially when climbing or walking, used to carry equipment, clothes etc
pack.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: a complete set of playing cards
pack.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: a group of wild animals that hunt together, or a group of dogs trained to hunt together
pack.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: a group of the same type of people, especially a group who you do not approve of
pack.translation[1].definitions[5].examp: A pack of reporters were waiting outside.
pack.translation[1].definitions[6].defin: a thick soft piece of cloth that you press on a wound to stop the flow of blood
pack.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: a small container with a set of things in it
pack.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Five million tickets to Disney films will be placed in specially-marked packs.
pack.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: a pack that contains six, twelve etc items
pack.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: This brand of beer is now available in 12-packs.
pack.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: to be more successful than your competitors
pack.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: It has fallen to seventh place in the ad-agency rankings, after leading the pack for three years.
The company is demonstrating the kind of innovation that will be needed to keep it ahead of the pack.
pack.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: a group of people who all work in the same industry, especially in films, the press, or the theatre, that you do not like or approve of
pack.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: The whole media pack is closing in on him.
pack.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: to put products in boxes, a vehicle etc so they can be taken somewhere
pack.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: At sixteen, Brian went to work packing freight on the shipping docks.
The video equipment is packed in aluminum trunks and air-freighted to the site.
pack.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: to put a lot of information onto the part of a computer or other piece of ELECTRONIC equipment that stores DATA
pack.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: The disks are engineered to pack at least twice as much data onto their recording surface.
pack.translation[3].definitions[2].defin: to arrive in large numbers into a space that is not big enough, or to make people or things do this
pack.translation[3].definitions[2].examp: Because moviegoers haven’t been packing the theaters this fall, they haven’t seen the trailers for our new releases.
The TV network has infuriated viewers by packing an extra three minutes of commercials into popular hour-long programs.
pack.translation[3].definitions[3].defin: to secretly and dishonestly arrange for most of the people on a committee etc to support someone
pack.translation[3].definitions[3].examp: He packed the company’s board with his relatives.
